title: Cannot disable completely
body:
<!-- Please search existing issues to avoid creating duplicates -->
<!-- Please attach logs to help us diagnose your issue -->

- Copilot Chat Extension Version: Not installed
- VS Code Version: 1.102.3
- OS Version: 10.0.26100
- Feature (e.g. agent/edit/ask mode): Copilot Window
- Selected model (e.g. GPT 4.1, Claude 3.7 Sonnet): none
- Logs: none

Steps to Reproduce:

1. open visual studio code
2. see copilot window open by default

I absolutely never want to use copilot. I never want to even see it. I want the simple ability to stop it from displaying every single time I launch the editor. Ideally I want to be able to uninstall it completely so I never have to deal with it. I'm not interested in vibe coding, nor am I interested in using a large language model to generate code that compiles on the first try less often than the code I write myself. 

It is impossible for me to care less than I already do about what the shareholders think about AI. I believe it to be a poison that ruins everything it touches, and I believe that anyone who uses it is a fool.

title: Spell Check Support in VS Code Copilot Chat
body:
<!-- ⚠️⚠️ Do Not Delete This! feature_request_template ⚠️⚠️ -->
<!-- Please read our Rules of Conduct: https://opensource.microsoft.com/codeofconduct/ -->
<!-- Please search existing issues to avoid creating duplicates. -->

<!-- Describe the feature you'd like. -->

Enhance the usability of GitHub Copilot Chat by integrating real-time spell checking within both the chat sidebar and inline chat inputs. This feature would highlight misspelled words and offer correction suggestions, similar to the existing spell check functionality in standard editors. It would improve communication clarity, reduce typos in prompts, and help maintain professionalism in team environments.

Optional Settings:
- Toggle spell check on/off.
- Support for multiple languages.
- Ignore certain words (e.g., code-specific jargon).

title: Unable to start integrated terminal with built-in WSL profile
body:
Type: Bug Trying to open a new integrated terminal tab using the built-in WSL profile for "Alpine (WSL)" shows this error: ``` <3>WSL (9 - Relay) ERROR: CreateProcessCommon:640: execvpe(/bin/bash) failed: No such file or directory ``` Then the tab closes shortly after with the error notification Based on the error message, I investigated a little and looks like this error is due to #248438 changing (for some Windows versions including mine) the executable to start the built-in WSL profiles from the preferred `/wsl.exe` to the deprecated `/bash.exe`. Seems like `/bash.exe` is trying to spawn `/bin/bash` within the distro, which does not exist for Alpine. `/wsl.exe` correctly spawns the default shell. ----------------- VS Code version: Code 1.102.3 (488a1f239235055e34e673291fb8d8c810886f81, 2025-07-29T03:00:23.339Z) OS version: Windows_NT x64 10.0.19045 Modes:

title: Premium Requests Not Allowed
body:
- Copilot Chat Extension Version: 1.350.0
- VS Code Version: 1.102.2
- OS Version: Sequoia 15.4.1
- Feature (e.g. agent/edit/ask mode): Premium Requests
- Selected model (e.g. GPT 4.1, Claude 3.7 Sonnet): Claude Sonnet 4
- Logs: "You have exceeded your premium request allowance..."

Steps to Reproduce:

I have maxed out my premium requests allowed under my plan.

I have explicitly turned OFF the stop-usage budget limit for Premium Requests so that I can continue to make premium requests at a pay-per-call rate, yet all of my premium requests are still being rejected and redirected to GPT 4.1.

What's worse is that now I am not even able to use the included gpt-4o model either. It redirects my model to gpt-4.1 automatically and tells me that I have run out of premium requests, even though gpt-4o is NOT a premium model. There seems to be a bigger bug going on here.

Occasionally, I am able to make a premium request if it's the first message in a new conversation. Otherwise, it rejects all of my premium requests (even though my stop-usage setting is turned off) and redirects to GPT 4.1.

Please fix for your paid subscribers.

title: Add command to open terminal in new window
body:
This PR adds a new VS Code command `workbench.action.terminal.newInNewWindow` that creates a new terminal directly in a new window, complementing the existing "Move Terminal into New Window" command that moves existing terminals.

## What's new

**Command**: "New Terminal in New Window"
- **ID**: `workbench.action.terminal.newInNewWindow`
- **Keyboard shortcut**: `Ctrl+Shift+Alt+`` (Windows/Linux), `Cmd+Ctrl+Shift+Alt+`` (macOS)
- **Available in**: Command Palette (F1)

## Behavior

When executed, the command:
1. Creates a new terminal instance
2. Opens it directly in a new auxiliary window (separate from the main VS Code window)
3. Automatically focuses the terminal for immediate use

## Implementation details

The implementation follows established VS Code patterns:
- Uses `AUX_WINDOW_GROUP` constant to open the terminal in a new window
- Includes proper preconditions (`TerminalContextKeys.processSupported` or `webExtensionContributedProfile`)
- Added to `DEFAULT_COMMANDS_TO_SKIP_SHELL` list for proper shell integration
- Follows the same action registration pattern as other terminal creation commands

## Files changed

- `src/vs/workbench/contrib/terminal/common/terminal.ts` - Added command ID enum and skip shell entry
- `src/vs/workbench/contrib/terminal/common/terminalStrings.ts` - Added localized string
- `src/vs/workbench/contrib/terminal/browser/terminalActions.ts` - Implemented action with keybinding

## Command comparison

- **"New Terminal"**: Creates terminal in current window
- **"Move Terminal into New Window"**: Moves existing terminal to new window  
- **"New Terminal in New Window"** ⭐: Creates NEW terminal directly in new window

This provides users with a more direct workflow for creating terminals in separate windows without having to first create a terminal and then move it.

Fixes #258895.

title: Editable virtual documents with save handler

labels.name: *dev-question
labels.description: VS Code Extension Development Question

body:
<!-- ⚠️⚠️ Do Not Delete This! feature_request_template ⚠️⚠️ -->
<!-- Please read our Rules of Conduct: https://opensource.microsoft.com/codeofconduct/ -->
<!-- Please search existing issues to avoid creating duplicates. -->

<!-- Describe the feature you'd like. -->
I'd like to share a feature for extension developers:
# Current situation
Suppose you have registered a `TextDocumentContentProvider` registered for a certain type of URI and you open a document with it. You can do it like this:
```
const doc = await vscode.workspace.openTextDocument(uri);
await vscode.window.showTextDocument(doc, { preview: false });
```
This will open an editor in read-only mode. So the user has no way of changing anything.
You can also open it like this:
```
const doc = await vscode.workspace.openTextDocument({content: 'some nice content'});
await vscode.window.showTextDocument(doc, { preview: false });
```
Now the file can be edited, but it's not associated with any URI. Pressing Ctrl+S will prompt the user to store a new file somewhere. Registering to `vscode.workspace.onDidSaveTextDocument` or `vscode.workspace.onWillSaveTextDocument`doesn't help either.

# Desired new feature
I would like to be able to open a *writable* editor with a virtual document inside it (content provided from `TextDocumentContentProvider` or directly via parameter). When saved, it should not prompt the user to put it somewhere in the file system but should instead evoke another handler that will do something with the changed state, like storing it. That handler could be on `TextDocumentContentProvider` or a handler you have to register in the workspace. I don't want to create a `FileSystemProvider` since it's overkill for this purpose. 

The idea is to be able to edit items with multi-line text using a fully featured editor. Such items could be e.g.
* fields with multiple lines in a database
* objects in Kubernetes like in K8S dashboards
* issues in Github
* multi-line version control commit messages (just for the sake of an example)

body:
<!-- ⚠️⚠️ Do Not Delete This! bug_report_template ⚠️⚠️ -->
<!-- Please read our Rules of Conduct: https://opensource.microsoft.com/codeofconduct/ -->
<!-- 🕮 Read our guide about submitting issues: https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/wiki/Submitting-Bugs-and-Suggestions -->

Does this issue occur when all extensions are disabled?: Yes/No
not relevant
<!-- 🪓 If you answered No above, use 'Help: Start Extension Bisect' from Command Palette to try to identify the cause. -->
<!-- 📣 Issues caused by an extension need to be reported directly to the extension publisher. The 'Help > Report Issue' dialog can assist with this. -->
- VS Code Version: 1.102.3
- OS Version: Kali GNU/Linux Rolling 2025.2


Hello, vscode again isn't providing a mechianism for removing unncessary architectures in linux installation like armhf and arm64. although I have transformed the sources file to DEB822 format as suggested in issue #238697 
this is really annoying and I suggest for maintainers to either stop modifying the vscode.sources file after every installation or allow users through specific configuration setting to set the architectures they want to download



Steps to Reproduce:
1. execute in terminal `cat /etc/apt/sources.list.d/vscode.sources` or cat `/path/to/your/vscode.sources` if you are in a different distribution than a debian-based. you should see output similar to the following:
```
### THIS FILE IS AUTOMATICALLY CONFIGURED ###
# You may comment out this entry, but any other modifications may be lost.
Types: deb
URIs: https://packages.microsoft.com/repos/code
Suites: stable
Components: main
Architectures: amd64,arm64,armhf
Signed-By: /usr/share/keyrings/microsoft.gpg
```

2. remove arm64 and armhf from "Architectures" in the  **/etc/apr/sources.list.d/vscode.sources** file, so only amd64 will be specified 
3. update vscode through: `apt update && apt install code`
3. observe that the unnecessary architectures were added again to the same sources file

title: MCP: Streamline installation of servers that depend on extra apps/CLIs
body:
Most MTP servers work out of the box remote or an easily installable package.

Some popular MCP servers require existing applications or CLIs:
1. Figma runs as SSE in the Figma app and needs Dev Mode enabled: https://www.figma.com/blog/introducing-figmas-dev-mode-mcp-server/
2. Snyk uses `snyk mcp`: https://docs.snyk.io/cli-ide-and-ci-cd-integrations/snyk-cli/developer-guardrails-for-agentic-workflows/snyk-mcp-early-access

We can't just drop the MCP config into VS Code and leave the user struggling. Installing those servers requires more guidance and troubleshooting.

- Show setup link/description after installation for details
- Show a troubleshooting link when the server fails to start. cc @connor4312 
- Optional scrips that can detect and guide setup for any dependencies.
- _Other ideas?_

title: Generic error when node not in PATH when starting MCP server
body:
> When launching an extension or language server that requires Node.js, if Node.js is not installed or not in the system PATH, VS Code currently shows a generic error (e.g., "env: node: No such file or directory").
> 
> It would be helpful if VS Code could detect this scenario and display a clearer, actionable error message, such as "Node.js is required but was not found in your PATH. Please install Node.js and try again."
> 
> This would make it much easier for users to diagnose and resolve the issue.
> 
> Originally reported at https://github.com/Azure/azure-mcp/issues/62

 _Originally posted by @chidozieononiwu in [#256355](https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/issues/256355#issuecomment-3137295165)_

title: Bug: Extension fetch() with AbortController timeout >300s closes connection at 300s
body: Does this issue occur when all extensions are disabled?: Yes/No - VS Code Version: 1.102.3 (Universal) - OS Version: Darwin arm64 25.0.0 Expected behavior: Timeout >300s on fetch() is respected. Actual behavior: Fetch times out at 300s Steps to Reproduce: 1. Within the extension environment, create a fetch request with a timeout exceeding 300 seconds. 2. The fetch will fail at 300 seconds. I created a lightweight extension and node.js server to demonstrate this: https://github.com/claytonmark/vscode-fetch-timeout-example Core components are: (extension fetch code) ``` const url = message.url || 'http://localhost:3000'; const timeoutMs = parseInt(message.timeout) || 10000; // Log the test parameters logToOutput(outputChannel, `Testing fetch timeout on ${url} with ${timeoutMs}ms`); const controller = new AbortController(); const timeoutId = setTimeout(() => controller.abort(), timeoutMs); const response = await fetch(`${url}/ping?sleep=${(timeoutMs/1000) - 5}`, { signal: controller.signal }); clearTimeout(timeoutId); const data = await response.json(); logToOutput(outputChannel, `Request succeeded after ${elapsedTime}ms`); ``` (server code) ``` const server = http.createServer((req, res) => { // Parse the URL and query parameters const parsedUrl = url.parse(req.url, true); const path = parsedUrl.pathname; // Only handle /ping endpoint if (path === '/ping') { const sleepDuration = parseInt(parsedUrl.query.sleep || '0'); // Validate sleep parameter if (isNaN(sleepDuration) || sleepDuration < 0) { res.writeHead(400, { 'Content-Type': 'application/json' }); res.end(JSON.stringify({ error: 'Invalid sleep parameter' })); return; } console.log(`Received request with sleep=${sleepDuration}s`); // Calculate response delay in milliseconds const delayMs = Math.max(0, (sleepDuration * 1000) - 5000); setTimeout(() => { const startTime = Date.now(); res.writeHead(200, { 'Content-Type': 'application/json', 'Access-Control-Allow-Origin': '*' }); res.end(JSON.stringify({ pong: delayMs })); console.log(`Responded after ${delayMs}ms`); }, delayMs); } else { // Handle 404 for other paths res.writeHead(404, { 'Content-Type': 'application/json' }); res.end(JSON.stringify({ error: 'Not found' })); } }); ``` Within the debugger, I placed a breakpoints at: * `app/node_modules/undici/lib/core/connect.js:83` * `app/node_modules/@vscode/proxy-agent/out/index.js:535` and observed that the AbortController is passed within `index.js:535` but the timeout in `connect.js:83` is undefined. I have limited experience in Node.js and VSCode extension development and I am not sure if the bug is in VSCode's patcher or the undici client library. Please let me know if this issue should be raised within undici.

body: Fixes https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/issues/258557#event-18883432995 and https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/issues/258619#event-18884722720 This PR handles 2 separate kinds of worktree errors: (1) when a user wants to create a worktree at a path where a worktree already exists and (2) if a user attempts to check out a branch that already has a worktree. title: Feature request for Copilot Chat. MCP Client improvement - Decrease token use, increase quality: Dynamic tool selection

labels.name: invalid
labels.description: Issue identified as not relevant or not valid

body: We need to improve the MCP Client for the [VSCode Copilot Chat](https://github.com/microsoft/vscode-copilot-chat). Currently, all tools are simply added to the context window consuming tokens, creating [Context Rot](https://github.com/chroma-core/context-rot), meaning worse results for more tokens/money. To fix that I think it’s appropriate to implement MCP-RAG on the MCP Client end to pull a list of semantically close tools for each user prompt dynamically. Suggested embedding model: codestral-embed from Mistral. And [Mxbai-rerank-v2](https://pub.towardsai.net/run-mxbai-rerank-v2-with-infinity-4b73858cd644) to improve performance for, code, MCP, and tool retrieval. Suggested Embedded (In-Progress) VectorDBs: https://github.com/tursodatabase/turso https://github.com/chroma-core/chroma https://github.com/lancedb/lancedb Some ideas on how https://github.com/modelcontextprotocol/modelcontextprotocol/discussions/845

title: Fix IntelliCode starred suggestions inserting star prefix in terminal REPL
body:
When IntelliCode provides starred completion suggestions in the terminal REPL (when typing `python` in the terminal), accepting them would incorrectly insert the star prefix along with the actual completion text. For example, accepting a starred suggestion for `chdir` would insert `★ chdir` instead of just `chdir`, resulting in invalid Python code like `os.★ chdir`.

![Image showing the bug where accepting a starred suggestion inserts the star](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/3d459325-34fe-407e-84aa-ba78799313cb)

## Root Cause

The issue occurred in the terminal completion provider (`src/vs/workbench/contrib/terminalContrib/suggest/browser/terminalSuggestAddon.ts`) where the completion text extraction in the `acceptSelectedSuggestion` method was falling back to using the `label` when no explicit `inputData` property was provided by the completion provider:

```typescript
let completionText = typeof completion.label === 'string' ? completion.label : completion.label.label;
```

For IntelliCode starred suggestions:
- The `label` contains the star prefix (e.g., "★ chdir") for display purposes
- No explicit `inputData` property is provided
- The fallback logic incorrectly used the starred label as the completion text

## Solution

Added a targeted fix that strips the IntelliCode star prefix when using the label as completion text:

```typescript
// Strip star prefix from IntelliCode starred suggestions when using label as completion text
if (completionText.startsWith('★')) {
    completionText = completionText.substring(1); // Remove "★" prefix
    // Also remove a following space if present for clean formatting
    if (completionText.startsWith(' ')) {
        completionText = completionText.substring(1);
    }
}
```

This fix:
- Removes the IntelliCode star character (★) regardless of what follows it
- Handles cases like `★chdir`, `★ chdir`, `★.method`, etc.
- Only affects completions that fall back to using the label as completion text
- Preserves the original starred label for display purposes
- Maintains full compatibility with all existing completion scenarios
- Handles edge cases like different star characters and missing spaces

## Testing

Added comprehensive test cases to verify the fix handles all scenarios correctly:
- ✅ IntelliCode starred suggestions insert without the star prefix
- ✅ Normal completions without stars work unchanged
- ✅ Completions with explicit inputData are unaffected
- ✅ Other star-like characters are not modified
- ✅ Unicode handling is correct for the specific IntelliCode star character
- ✅ Various formats after the star (space, no space, dot, etc.) are handled correctly

Fixes #258686.

title: Fix terminal suggest up arrow navigation on first press
body:
When terminal suggestions are first displayed, pressing the up arrow key was hiding the suggest widget and navigating terminal history instead of moving to the previous suggestion. This created a confusing user experience where the first up arrow press behaved differently than subsequent navigation.

## Root Cause

The issue was caused by conflicting keybindings with different weights:

- `SelectPrevSuggestion` (weight: WorkbenchContrib + 1) activates when `HasNavigated` is true OR `UpArrowNavigatesHistory` is false
- `HideSuggestWidgetAndNavigateHistory` (weight: WorkbenchContrib + 2) activates when `HasNavigated` is false AND `UpArrowNavigatesHistory` is true

Since `UpArrowNavigatesHistory` defaulted to `true` and `HasNavigated` starts as `false`, the higher-weight history navigation command would execute instead of suggestion navigation.

## Solution

Changed the default value of `terminal.integrated.suggest.upArrowNavigatesHistory` from `true` to `false`. This ensures that when suggestions are first shown:

- Up arrow navigates to the previous/last suggestion (intuitive behavior)
- Down arrow followed by up arrow works the same as before
- Users who prefer the old behavior can explicitly set the setting to `true`

## Example

**Before (confusing):**
1. Trigger suggestions in Python REPL
2. Press up arrow → Widget hides and shows history

**After (intuitive):**
1. Trigger suggestions in Python REPL  
2. Press up arrow → Navigates to last suggestion in list

The change maintains full backward compatibility while providing a more intuitive default experience.

Fixes #258680.

title: SSh connections from wrong host when using X11 forwarding
body:

<!-- Please read our Rules of Conduct: https://opensource.microsoft.com/codeofconduct/ -->

<!-- 🔎 Search existing issues to avoid creating duplicates. -->
<!-- 🧪 Test using the latest Insiders build to see if your issue has already been fixed: https://code.visualstudio.com/insiders/ -->
<!-- 💡 Instead of creating your report here, use 'Report Issue' from the 'Help' menu in VS Code to pre-fill useful information. -->
<!-- 🔧 Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Does this issue occur when all extensions are disabled?: Yes/No

<!-- 🪓 If you answered No above, use 'Help: Start Extension Bisect' from Command Palette to try to identify the cause. -->
<!-- 📣 Issues caused by an extension need to be reported directly to the extension publisher. The 'Help > Report Issue' dialog can assist with this. -->
- VS Code Version: 
- OS Version: 

Steps to Reproduce:

1. ssh from one machine (Machine A) to another (Machine B) using -Y to enable x11 forwarding
2. run vscode in the remote terminal (Machine B) so that it displays on the local machine (Machine A)
3. Try to connect the workspace to a host that can only be reached from the remote machine (Machine C)
4. Errors because it is using ssh keys from the machine with the X server (Machine A), not the machine that can reach the one where work should be done (Machine C)

body:
Type: Bug While using Copilot, I often receive excessive and irrelevant code suggestions that disrupt my development flow. The constant pop-ups make it difficult to focus and type freely, especially when I’m working on something specific or already have a clear idea of what I want to write. It would be helpful to have more control over when and how suggestions appear — for example, a manual trigger mode or smarter context detection that reduces interruptions. Improving the relevance and timing of suggestions would greatly enhance the user experience. Thank you for considering this feedback.
